messageBody:
On 8/22/06, Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...> wrote:
>
>
> > 100% code coverage is not just impossible to obtain and maintain, it's
> also
> > deceptive and can make you think you are exercising your code in all
> > possible ways. Which is, of course, never true.
>
> Never say never. You have dismissed an absolute statement with an
> absolute statement. That only works in political ad campaigns. (and
> rebuttals to absolute statements :-)


Touché.

Let's just say that getting a coverage tool to indicate 100% is
close-to-impossible (and on a personal note, I think it's silly to strive
for that high anyway because you will hit a point of diminishing return way
before).

On top of that, if you reach this elusive 100%, you're still not sure you
really have 100% code coverage (and most likely, you don't, because the
number of paths through your code is astronomical).

An example from one of my hobbies: target shooting with a .22 rifle. I
> find that when I use large targets (1 inch diameter bulls eye) I shoot
> at about upper 80's% accuracy. When I shoot with smaller targets (half
> inch bulls eye), I shoot with lower 90's% accuracy. This seems
> counter-intuitive, but I've done it often enough to know that it's
> consistently true for me. The lesson that I have learned from this is
> that the small target seems more difficult and so I try harder and
> subsequently get a better result. The bigger target seems less of a
> challenge, so I relax a little and my scores drop.


I like this metaphor. There are other possible explanations, though, but
your point is well taken.

--
